title: theresa may hosts welcome party in downing street for british divers who saved thai football boys from cave
story: More than a dozen dive experts and support staff joined the PM at a reception in 10 Downing Street.Mrs May paid tribute to their bravery in risking their lives to rescue the divers and their football coach on the amazing rescue mission earlier this month.Those attending the event included Robert Harper, John Volanthen, Christopher Jewell, Connor Roe and Joshua Bratchley and Vern Unsworth.Mr Unsworth was recently locked in a public battle with Elon Musk, after the tech tycoon wrongly accused him of being a paedophile.The divers and support staff posed with Mrs May and Thai ambassador Pisanu Suvanajata outside the famous black door of Number 10.Speaking during the event, the PM said: This was an amazing rescue mission.On hearing about the boys who were trapped most people would have just stood by but you chose to go out there and do something about it.The eyes of the world were on you and I think I can speak for everyone when I say a huge thank you. John, you have said that you’re not heroes - well to most of us, you are.Sadly we know that a Thai diver, Saman Kunan, died during this mission. He lost his life saving the lives of others – a danger you also faced.The Thai PM has written to me to say thank you for the fantastic job you did and I know that everyone in this country would agree. We are all very proud of you.”Mr Volanthen said: “It was an honour to join the incredible effort to rescue of these boys and their coach, and I would like to personally add particular reference to the skill and dedication of the many military groups and civilians we worked alongside, especially the Thai Navy Seals.“I would also like to extend my thoughts to the family of Saman Kunan.”The group joined the rescue efforts after being called in by Thailands Navy Seals.They were forced to find their way through flooded caves to find the patch of dry land where the 12 boys were huddling.The dangers of the expedition were highlighted when diver Saman Kunan died during the rescue attempt.But miraculously, the British-led team managed to get every one of the kids and their coach out of the complex, and theyre all on track to make a full recovery.

title: ministers should scrap the mot test because it doesnt save lives and costs drivers 180 a year report says
story: The Adam Smith Institute said most car crashes are down to driver error rather than mechanical faults.Drivers would save nearly £180 on average if the tests were no longer compulsory, the think-tank added.In total, British motorists pay out £250million a year on MOT tests and unnecessary repairs which are needed to make cars pass, according to the report.The annual MOT was first introduced in 1960 and is compulsory for all cars which are at least three years old.Its supposed to improve road safety by making mechanical failures less likely - but the Adam Smith Institute said it actually makes little difference.Just 2 per cent of accidents are caused by mechanical problems in the UK - and in the US, where theres no equivalent of the MOT, the rate is the same.The reports author Alex Hoagland said: There’s no evidence that vehicle safety inspections improve vehicle safety.”The average MOT costs £33.60 - but according to the think-tank, motorists incur additional costs of £143 making minor repairs needed to pass the tests.As well as scrapping the MOT altogether, options suggested by the report include reducing it to once every three years, or applying it only to vehicles which are at least five years old.It also says ministers should put more resources into developing driverless cars which could save lives by eliminating driver error.Sam Dumitriu of the Adam Smith Institute said: “MOT tests are meant to prevent crashes and save lives, but they’ve never been put to the test themselves.

title: top ten irritants summer heatwave jane moore
story: First and foremost being the Met Office’s “Amber Alert” warning to stay in the shade, drink plenty of fluids and be sure to wear sunscreen and dark glasses.Come winter, of course, they’ll once again be treating us all like morons and doom-mongering about slippery pavements and hypothermia.Luckily for them, new research revealing the top ten list of what irritates us came out before their nannying nonsense and, therefore, a “sorry we missed you” note took first place, followed by the whirring wheel on a computer and losing work you didn’t save.Life’s irritants, eh? Oh, let me count the ways. And believe me, it goes waaaay past ten.In fact, there are so many I feel it easier to group them together under various categories. So here goes.Eat with their mouths open stop an interesting group conversation to tell a dull, long-winded story with no point to it are overweight but claim they barely eat anything are thin but claim they eat everything pepper every, like, sentence with, like, the word “like” (Exhibit A: Anyone on Love Island) noisily slurp drinks in the cinema don’t pick up their dog’s poo make every sentence sound like a question litter the countryside don’t control their children in public places barge on to a train while you’re trying to get off read over your shoulder put bags on seats park in disabled bays when they’re clearly not live in a trillion quid mansion but claim to be socialist are glued to their mobile phone while their kid hurtles towards a road junction on its micro scooterupload ALL their holiday photos on social media, even the really crap ones say “aaah” loudly after drinking something.Aaaaaargh!Passengers who applaud when a flight lands parents who allow their kids to continually kick the back of your seat for the duration of a flight airport/rail managers who fail to boost staff numbers at peak times of the year oncoming drivers who push their way down a narrow road when you’re already three­quarters of the way along it train passengers who talk loudly on a mobile phone or think everyone else wants to listen to their ghastly music too people who cough on a crowded Tube/train without covering their mouth tailgaters drivers who don’t say thank you when you let them in middle lane hoggers packing hand luggage for a quick exit and being forced to put it in the hold.Head lice (so pointless) “Smart” TVs that make you feel anything but when trying to use the damned things novelty ringtones printed signs with spelling errors (use a pigging dictionary)online sites that won’t accept your usual password because it doesn’t have 48 squillion characters in it packaging that Harry Houdini would struggle to open roadworks with no one working on them spam emails automated phone systems immovable price stickers.Passing waiters who, when you ask for something simple like a spoon, reply: “Hang on, I’ll just get your waiter for you” shop assistants who stalk you around the rails as if you’re about to nick something fellow shoppers who start turning the rack of cards while you’re still looking at it hairdressers who chat incessantly through the supposedly “relaxing” head massage bit waiters who automatically hand the bill to the man queue-pushers at the bar bags “for life” that break the second you leave the supermarket assistants who carry on their social chat while you stand at the till waiting to be served cashiers who comment, “Ooh, are you having a party?”when you’re buying your own weekly wine supply shoppers who abuse the “ten items or less” aisle. Unless it’s me, of course.Believe me, I’m just scratching the surface here.Send me your irritations and I’ll print the best next week.Meghan Markles unpleasant half-sister Samantha is at it again – this time berating her understandably estranged royal relative for paying tribute to Nelson Mandela.“How about you pay tribute to your own father?” she ranted. “Enough is enough.Act like a humanitarian, act like a woman.If our father dies, I’m holding you responsible, Meg.”What a Grade A nasty.Meanwhile, last week Meghan’s father Thomas spent his 74th birthday picking up a Happy Meal from fast-food joint McDonald’s.Which, considering he’s just had heart stents fitted to help clear clogged arteries, suggests that if he dies any time soon, the only person responsible would be him.High-end designer ­Burberry junks £28million of unwanted products each year.A Burberry source has denied claims that they don’t donate it to charity because they don’t want the “wrong people” ­wearing it, saying that the destruction is actually to ­protect the brand against counterfeiting. Hmmm.The fakes ­market will always ­flourish irrespective of how many originals are pulped.So why doesn’t ­Burberry donate the items to upmarket charity ­auctions where people can bid a lot of money for something they might have bought anyway and have the extra thrill of knowing their cash will go to a deserving cause?Model David Gandy says he was once chucked out of a Hugo Boss catwalk show “because I couldn’t fit any of the clothing”.But luckily for the legion of Mr Gandy’s female fans, he can clearly still squeeze his, ahem, lardy self in to a teeny tiny pair of ­Y-fronts.Nope, still not going to wear them.Former Olympic showjumper Lizzie Purbrick has been telling her side of the story after being convicted of criminal damage for spraying her former lover’s home with several litres of pig’s blood.As you do.Lizzie, 63, says that initially, her relationship with Tory peer Lord Prior was “bloody marvellous” after they “met at a dinner party in Norfolk – the hotbed of sex – and I moved in with him four days later.”Whoa. Hang on, rewind that. Genteel Norfolk a hotbed of sex?And lo and behold, two days after this revelation, a survey by our sister paper The Sun on Sunday revealed that the nookie capital of Britain is…drum roll…Norfolk.So quite what they’re putting in the water up there is anyone’s guess.But something tells me house prices are suddenly set to rise.Charlie, 45, told his brother Matthew on the phone: “I’d really like to go out for a bottle of wine. I’ve been let out for a cigarette but I’m very bored.”We’ll take that as a no, then.Activity badges for Guides, Rangers and Brownies have been revamped for the 21st Century.You’ll be relieved to know Moped Mugging isn’t one of them, but there’s “Mixology” which involves designing a menu of non-alcoholic cocktails, “Festival Goer”, Vlogging, Mindfulness, Human Rights, Conscious ­Consumer and Media Critic (everyone’s a bloody critic.) Cripes.During my brief time as a Brownie in the late Sixties, I only achieved the “Hostess” badge, which entailed making a cup of tea for some visiting dignitaries at our local community centre and helping an elderly woman across the road.She didn’t want to go but, hey, a badge is a badge.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit negotiations remainer coup
story: The Prime Minister announced she was taking personal control of the talks with the EU, boosting the role of her controversial Brexit guru Olly Robbins.And she confirmed The Sun’s revelation last week that Mr Robbins was to harvest almost 100 staff from the Department for the Exiting the EU and bring them under his command at the Cabinet Office’s secretive Europe Unit.Mr Robbins will have overall responsibility for the preparation and conduct of the negotiations leaving new Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab in charge of getting the country ready for all exit scenarios - including No Deal.Mr Raab will step up preparations for leaving the EU next year without a deal in place by replacing his lost staff with new emergency planning officials.He attempted to dismiss the power grab as “moving the Whitehall deck chairs” but admitted there had been tensions between Mr Robbins and his predecessor David Davis.But former Brexit Department Chief of Staff Stewart Jackson branded it a “long predicted defenestration” that was a “transfer of power to the unaccountable Cabinet Office Europe Unit and hard core Remainers.”In a rare public appearance Mr Robbins rejected claims of a “coup detat” and insisted that he had not secretly gone behind the back of Mr Davis and forced his walk out.However the powerful mandarin admitted that Mrs May had tasked him with drawing up secret alternative plans two weeks before the crunch Cabinet showdown earlier this month at Chequers.Appearing at the Commons Brexit committee, Mr Robbins insisted that he had not sidelined Mr Davis or torn up the Brexit departments own Brexit blueprint, rather the position had “evolved”.However when confronted by MPs that Mr Davis had directly contradicted his version of events, the civil service high flyer would only shrug.Mr Jackson had accused Mr Robbins of running shadow, parallel operation and keeping officials and ministers from the Brexit department in the dark about the Chequers plan.But the civil servant hit back at  claims the plans were secret - insisting he had the full blessing of the PM to look at different options. He said: There was never a second secret White Paper” but “ministers had a series of papers before them”He insisted “there was not sudden twist in the road where one White Paper was done away with and another was written.”Dominic Raab is highly competent and a Brexiter. Naturally, he’s the last person No10 would want involved in talks.Instead our PM and her Remainiac aide Olly Robbins will do it. Raab’s sole role is preparing Britain for the outcome.We warned Mrs May after Chequers she will not survive one more breach of a red line. But we hoped Raab would be around to keep her and Robbins honest.The omens are grim.Tory Brexiteer Craig Mackinlay said: “Quietly somewhere was  a coup detat going on.”Labours Shadow Brexit Minister Jenny Chapman said: Dominic Raab has been sidelined by the prime minister before he has even had the chance to get his feet under the table.When Mrs May became Prime Minister in 2016 she promised that the negotiations with Brussels would be led by a Brexiteer.She said: I will create a new department responsible for conducting Britain’s negotiation with the EU.It will be led by a senior Secretary of State – and I will make sure that the position is taken by an MP who campaigned for Britain to leave the EU. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: london tube temperature heatwave uk weather cattle
story: Images from camera firm FLIR showed stifling conditions on the Central Line amid the ongoing record-breaking heatwave.While above ground temperatures are hitting an already sweltering 34C, recordings on the Underground showed it was nearly 10C hotter, breaching EU regulations for moving livestock.Transport for London said: “We understand travelling can be uncomfortable.There are air conditioned trains serving 40 per cent of the network.Customers should ensure they have water with them and contact a staff member if they feel ill.”Officials are now urging bosses to let staff have a lie in to avoid the rush hour heat.The Trade Unions Congress (TUC) has also suggested that some workers should be allowed to wear vests as the heatwave continues.It said staff should be allowed “frequent breaks” and the opportunity to leave their ties at home.The TUC added: “Giving workers the choice of coming in earlier or staying late will let them avoid the sweltering conditions of the rush hour commute.”General Secretary Frances OGrady, said: “The most simple way for staff to keep cool inside when it’s scorching outside is being able to work in more casual clothing.“While shorts and vest tops may not be appropriate for all, nobody should be made to wilt in the heat for the sake of keeping up appearances.“And bosses who provide a cool and comfortable work environment are going to get more out of their staff.The shocking findings come as shops run out of fans and sun-seekers defy health warnings to soak up the super-strength sun-rays.Yesterday was the hottest day of the year as temperatures reached 33.3C in Santon Downham in Suffolk.And it is set to get even hotter, with temperatures expected to peak on Thursday and Friday.On the Argos site, at least five of its most popular fans are in “limited stock” while Wilko has completely sold out of its £35 fan.Becky Mitchell, Met Office meteorologist, said temperatures of 35C were forecast for Thursday in East Anglia and London, adding: Theres potential it could go even warmer than that.She said the climbing temperatures are due to warm air coming up from France combined with high pressure across the country.A respite from the heat could come by the end of the week, when thunderstorms are expected in eastern areas.An amber heat health watch warning has been issued for parts of England.The amber, or level three, warning is issued when temperatures are predicted to hit 30C (86F) during the day, and 15C (59F) at night, for at least two consecutive days.

title: hostile eu uk daniel hannan opinion
story: Most Britons, whether they voted Remain or Leave, hoped that we would replace EU ­membership with a close alliance.Pulling out of the Brussels institutions did not need to prejudice friendly relations with our neighbours.But it is becoming clear that Eurocrats do not see it that way. The 27 EU states, or most of them at any rate, might individually want good relations with us.But, in Brussels, there are plenty of officials who would rather see all sides suffer than watch Brexit succeed.If their view prevails, the implications go well beyond Brexit. For 70 years, Britain has been a European power.Although we kept our military ties with the other English-speaking democracies, our focus was the defence of Europe. It still is.There are, for example, British soldiers patrolling the borders of Poland and Estonia.The RAF is, to all intents and purposes, acting as Romania’s air force, responding to incursions into that country’s airspace. And so on.In intelligence and security, rather as with the Common Fisheries Policy, Britain puts a lot more than its share into the common pot.We have done so cheerfully because we saw European states as our allies, and felt that we had a stake in their security. But what if that feeling is no longer reciprocated?Visiting Germany on Monday, Jeremy Hunt, the Foreign Secretary, pointed out in measured and polite language that the EU could not expect to treat Britain aggressively without consequences.Now Mr Hunt is no Little Englander. He is an entrepreneur who made his money from language courses, is married to a Chinese woman and, after some soul-searching, came down on the side of Remain.But what he said is impossible to argue with. If the EU chooses to treat Brexit as a hostile act, the basis of European security will be undone — at the very moment that Donald Trump has made it clear that America is no longer interested in defending Europe.In almost every European speech since the referendum, Theresa May has said that she wants Britain to be the EU’s closest friend and strongest ally.But when have you ever heard those good wishes returned?The PM keeps saying she wants the EU 27 to succeed. EU leaders keep saying they want Brexit to fail.They mean it. Eurocrats are not offering Britain the kind of deal that they have with neighbours such as Norway and Switzerland.They think UK will just swallow what’s offered.If we want to remain in the single market, says chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier, then, unlike those countries, we’d have to give Brussels 100 per cent control of our trade policy — an impossible condition.But neither are they offering the kind of simple free trade deal that they have with, say, Canada and Japan.If we want a straightforward trade deal, Barnier says, we’d have to leave Northern Ireland under EU rules — an equally impossible condition.In other words, Britain won’t be allowed the friendly relations with the EU that other democracies take for granted.It is not for a lack of willingness on our side. In February, Theresa May told a Munich audience: “Europe’s security is our security. And that is why I say that the United Kingdom is unconditionally committed to maintaining it.”The EU’s response? To exclude us from the Galileo satellite programme on grounds that we could no longer be trusted.Well, fine. I never saw much point in the Galileo system, which was pushed by French leader Jacques Chirac to challenge the “technological imperialism” of America’s GPS system.Britain should now either go in with the Americans or create its own satellite system, possibly with friendly states such as Australia and Canada.But the point is, the EU’s logic goes well beyond satellites.If Brussels no longer sees us as an ally, we can hardly carry on behaving like one unilaterally, so to speak.While we talk of trade and co-operation, EU negotiators talk of border queues and grounded flights.Ireland’s prime minister, Leo Varadkar, even threatens to close his airspace.If such thinking wins out, we shall have no choice but to leave Europe to itself and turn our faces, as our ancestors did, to the open seas.That is not an outcome anyone should want, but we shall be ready if it comes.Understandably enough, you might say, given what feeble negotiators we have been so far. But Britain has a bad habit of switching from vague amiability to sudden resolve when it is almost too late.Such a moment is upon us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: python snake shed spot picture
story: Somewhere among the boxes, Nerf guns and blankets is a terrifying 2.5metre long python  -but can YOU spot her?Snake experts were called in Coolum in Queensland, Australia earlier this month after the stunned owner found the reptile cooling off inside.Max Jackson, from Sunshine Coast Snake Catchers 24/7, posted a picture of the snake after attending the call-out.He wrote on Facebook: Spot the Snake!There is a 2-2.5m Carpet Python hiding in this outdoor Coolum shed .... let’s see if you can find him!Users struggled to spot the slithery character.Many guessed it was running along the roof - wrongly.In fact, the lisping predator is coiled up to the left of the picture, under two black boxes.Carpet pythons often crawl into sheds and loft spaces during the cooler months to hide out.They are native to Australia, Papa New Guinea Indonesia, and the Solomon Islands.The reptiles can grow to four-metres in length, but despite their hefty size are not poisonous and dont pose any threat to humans.They eat birds, bats, lizards and small mammals - using their constricting powers to suffocate their pray.Still a shock to find during a ssssspring clean.

title: food and medical supplies in no deal brexit
story: Following The Sun’s revelations last week, the Brexit Secretary confirmed secret plans have been drawn up to stockpile processed foods to protect supply chains.But Dominic Raab said that the Government would not gather food - rather help industry “make sure that there’s adequate food supplies.”Mr Raab said he would not drip-feed out details of the planning but added: We will be issuing a series of technical notices which will, in a responsible and reassuring way, explain what we are doing to mitigate the risks while giving the full picture so that - whether its farmers or citizens or other businesses - they understand what their position is and what the support that we will provide is.It came as Health Secretary Matt Hancock revealed more detailed NHS plans in the event of a No Deal Brexit.He told MPs the department was working up options with industry for stockpiling medicines and other supplies but there was still work to do.He added: Obviously there will be a cost for this. We are seeking to avoid a no-deal Brexit, but departmental preparations are accelerating to ensure people’s health needs are provided in the event of a no-deal Brexit.Challenged about the prospect of a no-deal outcome, Mr Raab said that while there would be uncertainty in the short-term I think long-term actually we would still be able to thrive.But he risked a backlash after warning he had ‘no idea’ what would happen if Britain fails to negotiate a trade deal by the end of the transition phase in 2020 - adding “it was a good question.”Mr Raab told the committee it would be difficult to judge precisely when talks had reached a position where it was inevitable there would be no deal.Im confident we can avoid it with ambition, pragmatism and energy on both sides, he said.I cant give you a precise moment at which it will be clear that there is no deal.And he insisted the UK would not cower in talks with Brussels following concerns that a no-deal Brexit was becoming more likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: excluded school kids are being abandoned by the education system say mps
story: A “forgotten” generation of troubled pupils are not getting the education they deserve as teachers kick them out for an easy life – then forget about them.In a damning report, the Commons Education Committee said parents are being forced to deal with an exclusion system like the “Wild West” which favours schools over pupils.Committee chair Rob Halfon said there was a “lack of moral accountability” among many schools which have little incentive to keep on “difficult or challenging” students.He warned of an “alarming” increase in “hidden” exclusions - when pupils are unofficially removed from lessons.The report found excluded pupils, who are slotted into different forms of education, known as alternative provision (AP), are being failed by England’s education system.Figures published last week showed a hike in exclusions, with more than 40 children a day expelled and over 2,000 suspended from England’s state schools in 2016/17.The cross-party group of MPs called for a “bill of rights”, for pupils and their parents, including a commitment by schools to not rush to exclude pupils, and that they publish their exclusions rates each term.Mr Halfon added: “Today, we face the scandal of ever-increasing numbers of children being excluded and being left abandoned to a forgotten part of our education system which too often fails to deliver good outcomes for these young people.“Children in alternative provision are the forgotten children.“Too many young people are being failed by the system and not getting the education they deserve.“This is a vital issue of social justice and the Government should act now to ensure these young people can climb the ladder of opportunity.”There are at least 48,000 pupils being taught outside of mainstream and special schools during the year - excluding those that remain on the full register of their school.Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said: “These are the young people on the margins, who are at most risk of severely reduced life chances, and we all have a moral responsibility to look after them.”Ministers have announced a review of the exclusions in England’s state schools. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: council payment neil hargreaves gedling borough council
story: Neil Hargreaves, 47, was shocked to get a letter from Gedling Borough Council, Notts, saying he owed the minuscule amount in outstanding council tax.But the wily taxpayer will get his revenge by posting them a cheque — so it will actually end up costing the authorities to cash it.Neil, who works in transport, said: I could end up in court for 3p if I wanted to push it. I am going to pay it by cheque.The fiasco began as far back ago as 2014 when Neils fiancee moved in with him because they are planning to get married.He called up the council to cancel her tax and renew his.But he says that the next thing he knew he was being pestered for pennies.Neil said: I got a council tax demand notice for 3p. I have to pay it by July 30. Next it could be the red letter or the baliffs.I am gutted. I do not mind paying it but they are spending more on postage. Its stupid. It has been signed by a manager.He added: The council will have to pay for the cheque to be cleared.Its on purpose, because I cant believe they sent this letter to me.Fiancee Vicky Hill, 28, who works in customer services, said: Neil rang me on the way to work and said I have a council tax demand letter and I thought it was going to be quite a lot.When he said it was for 3p I thought you are having a laugh. It is a waste of taxpayers money.Gedling Borough Council said that the letter is sent out with all bills under a £1, explaining why they have received a closing statement.The council says it is common practice performed every day, as it is required by law.The final closing bill shows his account has been closed and a new one has been set up.The council said it would not send him to court for non-payment.

story: If that’s the case then surely we won’t be conceding any more to Brussels.The evidence on Friday — when the EU slapped down Theresa May’s Chequers offers — suggests otherwise.Hammond’s disparaging remark shows that Remainers are at the heart of Theresa May’s Government, running the show at the expense of Leave voices.This Government sees Brexit as a damage-limitation exercise rather than a golden opportunity for Britain to reinvent itself as a global and buccaneering free nation.How can we ever achieve Brexit in full if the Government itself is so institutionally Euro-phile? title: is all what it seems with public sector pay rise
story: Since last year's snap general election, a number of Conservative MPs have openly suggested they believe the squeeze on public sector pay contributed to the party's failure to win an outright majority.Far from fixing the roof when the sun is shining, the scrapping of the pay cap is more akin to the government trying to find cover from the scorching heat of the public sector anger and criticism to which it has been exposed.The removal of the pay cap has been in gestation since the autumn, but the culmination of that process on Tuesday is unlikely to see that anger dissipate.Although teachers will receive a pay boost of 3.5%, that remains well below the 5% increase that unions have been demanding."The offers we're hearing about fall far short of the expectations of the union's negotiating position so I'll be surprised if it meant there was no successful strike ballots as a result of this," said GMB spokesman Andy Prendergast.That said, the increase in teacher pay is above the rate of inflation - currently running at 2.3% based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI). Labour have argued any pay increase that is not above the rate of inflation amounts to a real-terms pay cut - not exactly something that screams "good news".So no surprise that pay bumps for the armed forces (2.9%) and prison officers (2.75%) are being described by the Treasury as being "well-above inflation".But pick apart those figures and the claim seems a little misleading.But Labour's shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, Peter Dowd, dismissed the announcement as "a mendacious PR exercise".Another point of contention is how these pay increases will be paid for.In March, it was announced that some NHS workers, such as nurses, were to receive a 6.5% average pay increase over the next three years.But, that came with a pledge of extra money from the Treasury. Tuesday's announcements do not - they will come from existing departmental budgets.The government insists most departments will be able to meet the extra costs by diverting funds from budget underspends elsewhere, and in doing so will ensure the rewards are "sustainable without an increasing burden of debt being passed onto future generations".As she spoke in the Commons, Ms Truss was met with jeers from the opposition benches.Labour MPs stood up to raise concerns that lack of additional funding would lead to cuts to public services and redundancies down the line.

title: line 18 face to face investigating londons gang life
story: The first gang member I spoke to was a guy called JC, who belonged to 410 in Brixton.He showed up wearing a stab vest. At first I thought it was for show but when I looked closer I saw loads of marks where people had tried to stab him.He said he wore it every time he left the house and without it, he&#8217d be dead by now. He said he can&#8217t leave his estate without being targeted. "People know my face," he shrugged.I left JC with a feeling of hopelessness. It was clear there was no way out for him. But at least he&#8217s still alive. Many of his friends are either dead or in jail.In our conversation, I didn&#8217t really learn much about why someone would join a gang. So, hungry to find out, I got in touch with another gang. I arranged to meet the Woolwich Boys, believed to control the drugs supply in southeast London. Their reputation is fierce.Eventually I was introduced to a guy named K1. Spending time with him, it was clear he had the respect of the rest of the gang, and they listened to what he said.When I set out on this journey I believed that young men join gangs because of a lack of opportunities. After spending weeks speaking to them, my view dramatically changed.It&#8217s clear to me now that the temptation of easy money and what they believe is an exciting lifestyle is too much to resist.The interesting thing is some of them regret that decision and now want to leave - but they don&#8217t know where to start.The only thing for certain is that if someone makes that decision to join a gang, it&#8217s going to be very difficult to go back.

They're gonna pull out a weapon and so are you - it's an eye for an eye.They don't do no fist fighting these days, it's 2018 - they're gonna pull something out on you and so are you.This is Woolwich and this is where we're all from and where we all hang around - this is just the hood.My gang are powerful around here. People know our faces and they know what we're about, at the end of the day. We do our thing and we're out here to make a living. If I walk around and people see my face, they know who I am. They see me and they know my name they go "wagwan bro?". I'm quite a known face around here.I like it that people know who I am. I like it.When I'm out I'm not fearful - but there is paranoia. Thinking who's there? Who's in that car over there? Who's that? Obviously you're watching what's going on.I know a couple youths who come from a good background and they know a couple mates who've done it and they say let me join in, I wanna do it.I know kids who've come from Chelsea, everywhere. Good, nice mum and dad - but they've chosen to do this, while some of us have no choice.Some of us come from estates, ghetto places and all you see around you when you walk out your house is youths standing on a street corner selling drugs, smoking drugs and you look at them thinking yeah, "I think I wanna be like them one day".Is this all worth worrying my parents? As my mate says, your mum only worries if she knows that you're in trouble. You don't chat to your mum about that stuff because you don't want to worry her. You make sure that every day you call or go back to see your parents.

title: pakistan election ex cricket star imran khan could be prime minister
story: His main opponent, the three-time former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, was arrested on corruption charges when he landed in Lahore from London earlier this month.He is now campaigning from prison in Islamabad and is reported to be suffering from health issues.In his place as candidate for the centre-right Pakistan Muslim League is his brother Shahbaz Sharif. Some 3,459 candidates, representing more than 100 political parties, are competing for 272 seats in the national assembly.Sixty seats are reserved for women while 10 have been kept aside for religious minorities including Hindus.

story: Dr Stefanie Johnson, from the University of Colorado's Leeds School of Business, and her co-authors wrote: "Populations with higher T gondii infection had greater intentions to start a business and higher levels of active entrepreneurship behaviours."Countries with higher T gondii prevalence generally had a lower fraction of respondents who cited 'fear of failure' as a factor preventing them from initiating a business-related enterprise."The research is contained in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B.The infection rarely produces symptoms apart from mild flu-like illness but it has also been linked to car accidents and suicide.

title: defence chiefs cancel plan build
story: NewsDefence chiefs cancel plan to build new Royal Navy warships after only one company bids for contractExperts warned the budget for designing and building a brand new warship was too low - and just one firm was able to make a viable bid&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor18:45, 24 JUL 2018News13 Duke-class frigates are being retired and replaced with just eight Type 26 Global Combat Ships (pictured) (Image: Publicity Picture)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPlans for new Royal Navy warships were plunged into disarray today after defence chiefs were forced to ditch a high-profile project. The Type 31e light frigate was trumpeted by ministers as a cheap replacement for an ageing fleet of anti-submarine vessels. Thirteen, Type 23, Duke-class frigates are being retired and replaced by just eight Type 26 Global Combat Ships. Ministers hoped to make up the shortfall in the Senior Service with five, &pound250million smaller ships which they branded the Type 31e. The “e” highlighted their hope to export it to allies. But experts warned the budget for designing and building a brand new warship was too low - and just one firm was able to make a viable bid.  Now, the Ministry of Defence has been forced to relaunch the competition to create a ship. But the &pound250million budget will stay the same. A spokeswoman insisted: “There have been no changes in our plans to procure a first batch of five new Type 31e frigates to grow our Royal Navy. “We still want the first ship delivered by 2023 and are confident that industry will meet the challenge of providing them for the price tag we’ve set. “This is an early contract in a wider procurement process, and we will incorporate the lessons learned and begin again as soon as possible so the programme can continue at pace.” While officials refused to reveal details of the bids received, citing commercial sensitivity, it is understood just one came in at the &pound250million limit. Sources said the single bid made an “effective and robust competition” impossible.

story: NewsMoment Tory Brexit Secretary is interrupted by news of his own demotionThe jingle of the Sky News phone app alert could be heard as Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab faced questions from the Commons Brexit Committee&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter16:18, 24 JUL 2018Updated17:14, 24 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWestminster aped TV farce The Thick Of It today after a Tory minister appears to have been interrupted at a hearing - by news of his own demotion. It came after the Prime Minister announced she is taking personal control of talks with Brussels - two years after Britain voted to leave. Mr Raab, who insisted he knew about the statement in advance, voted Leave and was appointed to his Cabinet job two weeks ago when David Davis resigned.  But now Mrs May has announced she'll lead talks with Brussels herself, and Mr Raab will be her deputy. Mrs May said: The Department for Exiting the EU will continue to lead on all of the Government’s preparations for Brexit: domestic preparations in both a deal and a no deal scenario, all of the necessary legislation, and preparations for the negotiations to implement the detail of the Future Framework. I will lead the negotiations with the European Union, with the Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union deputising on my behalf.

title: boy 5 never enjoyed birthday
story: NewsBoy, 5, has never had a birthday cake because crippling illness leaves him writhing in agony whenever he eatsSeriously ill Jude Carrington suffers from horrific symptoms when he eats - ranging from rashes to extreme abdominal pain&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNarbeh Minassian01:11, 25 JUL 2018Updated01:14, 25 JUL 2018NewsJude Carrington has spent his life in and out of hospital (Image: HertfordshireMercury/ WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A five-year-old boy is unable to eat because of a mystery condition which has baffled medics - meaning he's never had a birthday cake in his life.  Seriously ill Jude Carrington suffers from horrific symptoms when he eats - ranging from rashes to extreme abdominal pain. The young boy has been in and out of hospital in search of answers. Doctors have not been able to shed light on his illness and Jude relies on a feeding tube, which he calls Harold, to pump a hypoallergenic formula into his body for 19 hours every day. His family have been given an unexpected boost after a newlywed couple decided to lend their support - despite never having met Jude, from Hoddesdon in Hertfordshire.   His family are determined to raise &pound50,000 to fund research into his condition in America – and have been given a &pound5,000 boost, the Hertfordshire Mercury reports.  In lieu of gifts, Stephen and Nicky Broderick asked guests to support brave Jude’s journey after they were moved by his story in their local newspaper. The pair had tried for a baby of their own for years and after several rounds of IVF finally gave birth to daughter Grace, now eight. “We were about to get married in May and we were asked about wedding presents but we thought we had everything we need so decided to pick a charity instead,” said Stephen. “Then the next day I saw the story in the Mercury and it just touched a nerve.”  The couple made a commitment to guarantee &pound5,000 and their guests raised just under &pound4,000, meaning Stephen and Nicky put up around &pound1,000 of their own. Jude’s mum, Joanna, who said they have had donations from business, friends and strangers in the town, has been overwhelmed by the support for her boy. “We met them [Stephen and Nicky] last month to say thank you, they were just so generous,” she said.elp.” The family are now up to &pound17,000 and hope to get closer to their goal with a charity clairvoyance evening in August and with the help of local football team Soccer Rules, who have made Jude their charity of choice next season. The money could help the family to finally get to the bottom of their boy’s sickness, which causes his body to attack everything he eats and can leave Jude with bloody diarrhoea, among other symptoms.  “It has a massive impact on his life — so much of people’s social lives revolve around food,” Joanna explained in April, while choking back tears. “Jude’s never had a birthday cake, he’s never been able to have an ice cream when we go away on holiday. “We’ve just gone through Easter — he’s never had an Easter egg, there are no Easter egg hunts for Jude. “At school when there are birthdays I have to leave a bag of toys for him to be given when it’s time for cake so he doesn’t feel left out. As a baby, before the condition made itself known, Joanna and dad Steven said Jude loved trying different foods.  But as they pushed forward with weaning him onto a solid diet, the tot became “very unwell” with soon-to-be familiar symptoms including severe acid reflux, vomiting and abdominal distension, where his tiny stomach bloated uncontrollably. In addition to the symptoms he suffers when eating solid food, the Sheredes Primary School pupil also struggles with gastroesophageal reflux disease and gastroparesis. This means his stomach can’t empty itself fast enough and its contents spills back up into his oesophagus, meaning he has to be slow fed continuously whilst taking numerous medicines each day. “He can’t drink enough of what he needs to live, to grow and develop,” Joanna explained. “His stomach is not big enough to take it all in so we have to give him a pump to slowly feed him throughout the day. “His life is about medical routine. It’s always stop-and-start fun because he has to think about his medicine.” But despite everything Jude has had to go through, his parents couldn’t be prouder of his fighting spirit.

title: caf owning boat captain kicks
story: NewsCafé owning boat captain 'kicks mum off vessel because of her crying baby'Steph Shaddick, had gone to the the floating Café Onboard in Devon, with her two children Barney, one, and Nancy, five, before being asked to move outside&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlex RichardsSports writer22:11, 24 JUL 2018NewsSteph Shaddick says she was forced off the floating cafe (Image: DevonLive/ WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA caf&eacute owning boat captain who claims to have had enough of 'poor parenting' is claimed to have kicked a mum off his vessel because of her crying baby. Steph Shaddick, had gone to the floating Caf&eacute Onboard in Devon, with her two children Barney, one, and Nancy, five. She claims she was forced outside when Barney, who was crying loudly, became distressed. Captain and caf&eacute owner Robert Hunter defended his decision saying he had asked the 30-year old to take her baby to the outside seating area after he screamed 'for around 15 to 20 minutes' next to a queue of 20 hungry diners. He claims Steph was sat on her mobile phone rather than calming the child down - and that he is sick of mum's letting children run riot.  But the shocked mum said she was treated badly when she was made to carry a pram, a child, drinks and two meals through the crowded business, reports Devon Live .   Steph said the experience was some of the worst customer service she had ever witnessed. She explained: We went for chips on the boat, and when my youngest went to eat them they were too hot and he cried. There were a lot of foreign exchange students queuing up for ice creams at the time. The owner asked to 'take that screaming baby outside, this is not working for me.' He made us go outside with our cups, the pram and food. I had to manoeuvre through the students and had to sit on the side of a table outside. I felt like I had been pushed out. She added: He was just generally rude. He pointed outside and told us to go out very unpolitely, my baby wasn't being bad until then - it was just that he wanted the food. I have never had an experience in a business like this before. They are meant to be family friendly, there's a sign which says so, and its next to one of the biggest parks in North Devon.  Captain Hunter, who has run the cafe for around four and a half years ago, says he has 'put his life and soul into it.' Now he says he has 'had enough' with poor parenting on his family-friendly floating caf&eacute and even has a sign which reads: No barking dogs, no screaming kids and no loud mobile phones.' He explained: We had a mum come in and the baby was already crying while strapped into the pram. He was very close to the counter and the screaming got louder. It continued screaming and two people stood and asked my wife at the counter to do something about it. But we said it is up to the mother to do something. Then a queue began to form at the counter right next to the pram. The baby went ballistic at all these tall people towering over him. The mum did absolutely nothing, she was more focused on her mobile phone - she should have unstrapped him and carried him around. The screaming was so loud we could not hear what people wanted at the counter - the kid just go worse as he was overheated and distressed.

title: company lets staff take unlimited
story: NewsCompany lets staff take unlimited holiday - and it's had a surprising affect on the businessGradTouch, in Manchester's Northern Quarter, are pioneering a new way to work&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience WriterLucy Roue16:34, 24 JUL 2018NewsJoe Twigg and Zac Williams co-founded GradTouch (Image: MEN WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMost of us dream of exploring the world and trying new things in exciting new locations. But unfortunately there are two big things which get in the way - money and work. While we can't fix the money part, there's a company in Manchester which is helping its staff out with the work bit.  Recruitment start-up GradTouch has taken flexible working to a whole new level and is now offering staff unlimited annual leave, reports the Manchester Evening News .  And bosses have found it's having a really positive impact on their business, which is now growing faster than every.  Last year the average amount of holiday taken by their 22-strong team staff totted up to 46 days. Co-founder Zac Williams explains: We're huge believers in having a great company culture and we're pioneering a new way to work. We don't have set hours in our contracts, instead employees agree to focus only on results. We have an unlimited holiday policy and we encourage our staff to work from wherever they want, whenever they want. This includes the freedom to work from home or trendy coffee shops and only pop into the Northern Quarter HQ when they are required at meetings. The 29-year-old continues: It's not something that works for everyone. You have to be comfortable with autonomy and you have to be self-motivated to work in that system.  We got rid of contracted hours so all it says is that staff will do what needs to be done to get the job done - but in more legal language. In order for us to build this business we needed to hire people that are better than us and let them get on with their jobs. If you hire properly then you can build a culture based on empowerment and trust. Zac and co-founder Joe Twigg introduced the policy two years ago after a gruelling investment round which brought in &pound500,000. Zac said: Williams said: We were building the platform as quick as we could and a lot of people were doing really long hours.

title: huge dinosaur foot measuring more
story: NewsHuge dinosaur foot measuring more than three-feet wide belonged to 'one of the biggest beasts to walk in North America'The bones belonged to a plant-eating animal similar to the Brachiosaurus, star of the film Jurassic Park, scientists have confirmed&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent21:24, 24 JUL 2018NewsScientist poses with excavated dino foot (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dinosaur's foot measuring more than three-feet wide is the largest found to date. The bones belonged to a plant-eating animal similar to the Brachiosaurus, star of the film Jurassic Park, scientists confirmed today. It comes from the sauropod family of dinosaurs, which had long necks and tails and were the largest animals to roam the earth. “Bigfoot”, found near Mount Rushmore, confirms brachiosaurs lived over a huge swathe of North America, from eastern Utah to northwestern Wyoming, 150 million years ago. Study co-author Dr Emanuel Tschopp, of the American Museum of Natural History, said: “This is surprising. Many other sauropod dinosaurs seem to have inhabited smaller areas during that time.  “There are tracks and incomplete skeletons from Australia and Argentina that seem to be from even bigger animals, but found without feet. “This beast was clearly one of the biggest that ever walked in North America.” The foot was excavated in 1998 but has been the subject of study for 20 years. The findings were published yesterday in PeerJ journal. Researchers from the US, Switzerland and Germany used 3D scanning to help compare the specimen to feet from different dinosaur species.

story: NewsInside disused pub where landlord let 40 people live in "appalling" conditionsHayden Rogers let out the Old Quay House pub in Flintshire, allowing 40 people to reside there with electrical faults, overloaded sockets, missing smoke and heat detectors and poor heating&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMarc Waddington18:27, 24 JUL 2018NewsUp to 40 people were found to be living in the The Old Quay House pub at Connah's Quay (Image: Daily Post Wales)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA landlord who let up to 40 people live in “appalling” conditions at a disused pub has been hit with almost &pound16,000 in fines. Fire escapes were also deemed inadequate and extinguishers were out of date.  Last year, an inspection saw the tenants removed from the pub, which the council said was “unsafe”.   Rogers was prosecuted by Flintshire Council, who said the property was in an appalling condition, reports the Daily Post .   The defendant didn’t turn up to court and the case went ahead without him.  Rogers was convicted of not having a house in multiple occupation (HMO) licence, and fined &pound2,000 after being found guilty in his absence.  He was found guilty of 11 breaches of the regulations, racking up a &pound1,000 fine per offence.  With Flintshire council and the court’s costs, he ended up with a bill of &pound15,633.

story: NewsKate Middleton did something incredible for Prince George the day after she gave birth to his little brother LouisKate Middleton gave birth to her third child, Prince Louis, in April - but she was determined to keep things as normal as she could for her other children Prince George and Princess Charlotte&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer15:55, 24 JUL 2018Updated22:45, 24 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new arrival is a huge change for any family, and it can sometimes be hard for children to accept the new crying baby which is taking up all of mum and dad's attention.
